channel.title: Regarding Arch
channel.description: I'm a first time Linux user currently running Xubuntu, I was just wondering, would it be feasible for me to run with Arch with very basic knowledge, or should I stick to Xubuntu?

item.title: Regarding Arch
item.dc:creator: @solarwind solarwind
item.description:
@solarwind wrote:

A bit of advice: Arch Linux is easy to install, but you have to know what you’re doing in case something goes wrong. I installed it on my laptop today and GRUB completely messed up. The device maps were swapped around and I couldn’t boot at all (GRUB didn’t load) after installing. A normal noob would be stuck here and give up and probably go to best buy to buy a $2000 computer. So be careful.

It took me 5 minutes to realize, however, that the device maps were swapped around since I was installing via USB image (shouldn’t happen to everyone though). I had to boot into the live GRUB on the USB stick and reinstall GRUB and then recreate my menu.lst files in the live environment. The device maps were the toughest to figure out. But anything can be fixed, so don’t give up and give it a try.

Read full topic

Would you rather type “sudo apt-get install gnome” ?

Just random thought:
That wouldnt work on ubuntu though.
You would need to type sudo apt-get install ubuntu-desktop
[/quote]
Wow, just wow.[/quote]
Well, when I tried sudo apt-get install gnome on ubuntu server like a year ago it came up with package not found. using x/k/ubuntu-desktop, it worked.

item.title: Regarding Arch
item.dc:creator: @llib llib
item.description:
@llib wrote:

Nope.

The archwiki is really amazing though, I followed the beginners guide on how to install it and got it installed easily.

Just to let you know when you install arch off the cd, there will be no Gui you’ll have to download those packages. But if you follow the Beginners guide step for step you should be fine.

I <3 pacman

item.title: Regarding Arch
item.dc:creator: @Speljohan Speljohan
item.description:
@Speljohan wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:7, topic:259318”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=342401.msg2647964#msg2647964 date=1233357732]
Good luck, stick with it, it all clicks and makes sense after not so long
[/quote]

Im thinking of Installing Arch aswell but can you tell me whats so great about it. At the moment i have Puppy Linux because its amazing how you have a lightweight linux package with so many helpful programs with a GUI already in the distro.
Some people hate it becuase you have to use their own .pet packages but you can convert slackware .tgz into .pet so theres no problem[/quote]For one, arch has a great package manager (pacman) which is incredibly fast and easy to use. You have to install what you want manually, but it’s so damn easy. For example, a fully working http/php/mysql server install would only be:

pacman -S mysql php apache

And it would work out of the box!

Read full topic

item.title: Regarding Arch
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:

Mopman:

Good luck, stick with it, it all clicks and makes sense after not so long

Im thinking of Installing Arch aswell but can you tell me whats so great about it. At the moment i have Puppy Linux because its amazing how you have a lightweight linux package with so many helpful programs with a GUI already in the distro.
Some people hate it becuase you have to use their own .pet packages but you can convert slackware .tgz into .pet so theres no problem

Read full topic

item.title: Regarding Arch
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

Totally feasible. The install itself is as easy as any other operating system, you MAY hit a wall with the initial configuration, however:

Their wiki is AWESOME. Seriously, compared to Ubuntu etc the Arch community maintained documentation is fuckin’ enterprise level support. It has almost everything, its clear concise well maintained, it’s just ridiculously good.

The IRC channel is mostly friendly. There’s a little elitism, but just ignore those people and stay polite, and you will eventally get help.

There are a few arch diehards on here (including myself) who are more than willing to help you out with any specific questions or problems.

Good luck, stick with it, it all clicks and makes sense after not so long

Read full topic

item.title: Regarding Arch
item.dc:creator: @chrisn2323 chrisn2323
item.description:
@chrisn2323 wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:3, topic:259318”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=342401.msg2647459#msg2647459 date=1233331116]
There’s a tutorial on how to install it on their wiki. I’d say anyone could install it using that as it’s very easy to follow and will teach you quite a bit about linux under the hood.
[/quote]

If you have a decent PC running Xbunutu theres nothing wrong with keeping it, but as Speljohan said Arch will teach you a lot of things
I dont have Arch but I heard you need to type startx everytime you boot which would get annoying![/quote]
use runlevels or a graphical login as a daemon.

Read full topic
